questions.text: An 8-year-old child was brought with complaints of bilateral knee pain. On examination, he had pinpoint ecchymoses around the hair follicles. His X-ray appears as given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the X-ray image showing Pelkan spurs, Trummerfeld zone, Frenkel's line, and Wimberger's ring sign are suggestive of scurvy.

Scurvy results from the deficiency of vitamin C, which is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline. Hence, deficiency of vitamin C leads to defective collagen formation resulting in generalized bleeding tendencies.

Clinical features:

Early manifestations include irritability, loss of appetite, musculoskeletal pain, and tenderness in the legs. Later on, the child can have swelling of the knees, ankles, and pseudo paralysis. Hemorrhagic manifestations of scurvy include petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses at pressure points, epistaxis, gum bleeding, and characteristic perifollicular hemorrhages.

Other manifestations are poor wound and fracture healing, hyperkeratosis of hair follicles, arthralgia, and muscle weakness. It also results in defective osteoid formation. Costo-chondral separation leads to the formation of tender nodules, which are sharply angulated also known as the scorbutic rosary.

Radiographic features of scurvy include:

  • Wimberger's ring sign - sharp margination of the epiphysis by a sclerotic rim
  • White line of Frankel - calcified cartilage at metaphyses
  • Trumerfeld zone - a lucent zone beneath the Frankel's line due to lack of mineralisation of osteoid
  • Pelkan spurs - due to fractures at the cortical margin
  • Periosteal elevation - due to subperiosteal haemorrhages

 

Other options:

Option A: Rickets occurs due to vitamin D deficiency in children. The patients present with skeletal changes like bowing of legs and bone pain. Radiological features show cupping at metaphysis, fraying, and widening of the growth plate.

Option B: Caffey’s disease is infantile cortical hyperostosis. It usually presents at 6 months of age with painful soft tissue swelling and bone thickening. The mandible is the most common bone involved.

Option D: Osteogenesis imperfecta presents with the hallmark features of osteoporosis with increased fragility of bones along with blue sclera, dental fragility as well as hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text: You notice the following test is performed in an infant during your orthopedic postings. This test is useful in diagnosing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given test is the Plumb line test that helps to detect tibial torsion which is seen in CTEV.

The child is made to sit on a table with both the lower limbs hanging from the edge. A line is drawn from the center of the patella to the tibial tubercle when extended down should cut the foot at the first or second inter-metatarsal space normally. This is called as plumb line.

In CTEV, with medial rotation of the tibia plumb line cuts the fourth or fifth inter-metatarsal space.

A dorsiflexion test is done in the screening of clubfoot.

 

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: As per Sunderland's classification criteria for nerve injuries, injury to the endoneurium and the perineurium with an intact epineurium would be classified as:
questions.solution:
Injury to the endoneurium and the perineurium with an intact epineurium would be classified as grade 4.

 

Sunderland Classification of nerve injuries is based on the anatomical structure of the nerve. The degrees of injury are: 

  • 1°= Flow of axoplasm is partially blocked with no morphological changes. Recovery of function is complete ~ neurapraxia.
  • 2°= Axon loss occurs, but endoneurial tubes remain intact. Axons grow into their respective tubes during recovery, and the result is good ~ axonotmesis.
  • 3°= Injury to the endoneurium. During recovery, the axons of one tube can grow into another resulting in synkinesis.
  • 4°= Injury to perineurium in addition to above. Scarring impairs the regeneration of nerve fibers ~ partial transection.
  • 5°= Injury to epineurium in addition to above ~ complete nerve transection.

 

Related Pearl: Seddon's classification of nerve injuries

Seddon's classification includes 3 groups:

  1. Neuropraxia
  2. Axonotmesis
  3. Neurotmesis

Neuropraxia:

  • Reversible physiologic conduction block
  • Occurs due to mechanical pressure causing segmental demyelination
  • Examples: Saturday night palsy, tourniquet, and crutch palsy

Axonotmesis: 

  • Axonal interruption
  • Conduction is lost but the nerve is in continuity and neural tubes are intact
  • Examples: Closed fractures and dislocations

Neurotmesis: 

  • Division of the nerve trunk
  • Endoneurial tube destruction also occurs
  • Example: Complete section of nerve in open fractures

questions.text: A young male patient is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. The X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following is ideal for the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows a transverse fracture of the patella, and the ideal management for this is tension-band wiring.

The patient presents with pain and swelling over the affected knee. Patellar tenderness and bruise over the front of the joint can be present. Crepitus may be felt in comminuted fractures. The patient cannot lift his leg in full extension(extension lag) due to the disruption of the extensor apparatus. Hemarthrosis can be associated.

Patellar fractures can be transverse, longitudinal, polar, or comminuted.

The radiological examination includes AP and lateral views. A skyline view of the patella is required in some cases of undisplaced fractures.

Management of patellar fractures: 

Undisplaced fractures: It is treated with a plaster cast extending from the groin to just above the malleoli, with the knee in full extension. This is called a cylinder cast (option A) and is usually left in place for a period of at least 3 weeks.

A transverse fracture is treated by a surgical procedure consisting of the reduction of the fragments known as tension-band wiring and K- wire fixation. This is followed by the repair of the extensor retinacula and physiotherapy.

Comminuted fractures are treated by open reduction and fixation. Patellectomy (option C) is the preferred option in this case as restoration of a smooth articular surface is difficult in this condition. Patella-saving operations are recently more performed with advancements in fixation techniques.

Longitudinal fractures usually have intact extensor apparatus. They can be treated with a cylinder cast or extension brace initially, followed by a range of motion.

Complications are knee stiffness, extensor weakness, and osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient presents to the ER with severe pain and swelling in the right foot following a road traffic accident. The fracture line is as shown in the image. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?

choices.text: Head of the talus is likely to undergo avascular necrosis.
Osteoporosis in the dome of the talus results from avascular necrosis.
Osteoarthritis of the ankle is a common complication.
Mechanism of injury is likely to be excessive plantar flexion.

questions.solution:
The given scenario and image point to a diagnosis of a fracture of the neck of the talus, also known as aviator's fracture. Osteoarthritis of the ankle is a common long-term complication of this fracture. 

These fractures most commonly occur following a high-energy injury causing forced dorsiflexion of the ankle (Not plantar flexion - option D). The neck of the talus is forced against the anterior edge of the tibia, and the neck, being a weak area, gives away. The fracture of the neck of the talus is classified using Hawkins classification.

Complications of fracture of the neck of the talus include:

  • Avascular necrosis of the body of the talus (Not the head of the talus - Option A): Note that if the dome of the talus becomes osteoporotic, it is suggestive of retained vascularity and that the body will not develop avascular necrosis (Not a result of avascular necrosis - Option B). 
  • Secondary osteoarthritis of the ankle or the subtalar joints is seen after some years in over 50% of the patients with neck of talus fractures. 
  • Malunion

Undisplaced fractures are managed conservatively in a short leg cast for 8–12 weeks and a non-weight-bearing cast for 6 weeks. Fractures of Hawkins types II-IV are managed by open reduction with internal fixation (ORIF).

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is false regarding the modality that is considered the investigation of choice for diagnosis of osteoporosis?

BMD- Bone mineral density

choices.text: T-score of < -1 in the total hip is considered osteoporosis
T-score of < -2.5 in the femoral neck is considered osteoporosis
Bone spurs may cause increased BMD values
Small thin people tend to have less than average BMD

questions.solution:
T-score of < -1 in the total hip is considered osteoporosis is false. 

The investigation of choice for the diagnosis of osteoporosis is DEXA (dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry). A T-score <–2.5 in the lumbar spine, femoral neck, or total hip has been defined as osteoporosis.

DEXA measures the bone mineral density of an individual. In the DEXA technique, two X-ray energies are used to estimate the area of mineralized tissue, and the mineral content is divided by bone area, which partially corrects for body and bone size. However, as this is a two-dimensional method, the correction is not adequate and small slim people tend to have lower BMD as compared to the average.

Also, bone spurs, tend to falsely increase bone density, and are a particular problem in measuring spine BMD in older individuals.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who was non-compliant with his tuberculosis medication now comes with back pain. You suspect the disease has disseminated to the spine. Which part in the given image of the spine, is most commonly affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the patient is likely to have developed tuberculosis of the spine. The most common pattern of involvement in Pott's spine/ Tb spine is the paradiscal type.

The structures marked in the image:

  1. Posterior spinal elements
  2. Paradiscal area of the vertebra
  3. Anterior vertebral body
  4. Central vertebral body

Tb spine occurs secondary to a pulmonary or gastrointestinal primary and spreads through the Batson's plexus of veins (paravertebral plexus). It most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region. 

Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

  • Paradiscal - contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae and the middle intervening disc are affected. This is due to the high oxygen requirements of tubercular bacteria and the corresponding high blood supply in this region by the segmental vessels.
  • Central - the body of the vertebra is involved leading to collapse (causing wedging or concertina) of the affected vertebra. This leads to spinal deformities such as kyphosis and gibbous.
  • Anterior - the anterior part of body is affected and spreads through the anterior longitudinal ligament.
  • Posterior - the posterior complex (pedicle, lamina, spinous process, and transverse process) is affected.

Image showing various parts and patterns of involvement in Pott's spine.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady with a known case of hypothyroidism presents with pain and burning of the lateral half of the palm. On examination, her palms appear as shown below and Phalen's test is positive. What is the likely structure under which the affected nerve is compressed?
questions.solution:
The image shows atrophy of thenar eminence as seen in carpal tunnel syndrome. It is due to compression of the median nerve where it passes under the flexor retinaculum in the wrist.

Patients present with pain and paresthesia over the distribution of the median nerve. There may be a weakness of thumb opposition. In chronic cases, the thenar eminence is wasted.

Tinel's sign will be positive. This sign is elicited by percussing over the median nerve, reproducing symptoms. In Phalen's test,  the symptoms are reproduced by holding the wrists in full flexion for 60 seconds.

Carpal tunnel syndrome can be associated with rheumatoid arthritis, pregnancy, chronic renal failure, acromegaly, hypothyroidism, and gout. The diagnosis is usually made on clinical grounds but nerve conduction studies can confirm the diagnosis.

The following image shows Phalen's test.

Other options 

Option A- Ligament of Struthers connects the medial epicondyle and the humerus. It is associated with pronator syndrome due to the involvement of the median nerve and produces similar symptoms as carpal tunnel syndrome. However, Phalen's test is negative.

Option B- Bicipital aponeurosis is the insertion of the biceps in the cubital fossa. It is also associated with pronator syndrome due to the involvement of the median nerve. Phalen's test is negative.

Option C- Guyon's canal: The ulnar nerve can get compressed while passing through Guyon's canal.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an early complication of fracture?
questions.solution:
Complex regional pain syndrome -CRPS(earlier known as Reflex sympathetic dystrophy or Sudeck's dystrophy or algodystrophy) is a late complication of fracture. Rest options are early complications

CRPS is divided into 2 types. CRPS type 1 occurs after trivial trauma or fracture and is explained below.

It occurs as a sequela of trauma and presents as a swollen, tender, and painful condition. It progressively undergoes atrophy of skin, muscle, and even nail over weeks resulting in fixed deformity at last. X-rays classically show spotty or patchy rarefaction. Earlier recognition and treatment initiation makes the prognosis relatively better.  Long term physiotherapy together with analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs form the mainstay of treatment. Ganglion blockers in resistant cases can improve the condition.

CRPS type 2 is related to causalgia after nerve injury.

questions.text: A cast was applied to a patient with a wrist injury as shown below. What is this cast known as?
questions.solution:
The cast applied to a patient in the glass holding position is known as the scaphoid cast. It is used to treat scaphoid fractures.

To apply a scaphoid cast, the wrist is held in slight dorsiflexion and the thumb is in abduction and slight flexion as if the glass is being held between the index finger and thumb. It extends from just below the elbow to just proximal to the metacarpal necks of the digits. On the thumb, the cast extends just proximal to the interphalangeal joint.

Scaphoid fracture presents with pain and swelling over the radial aspect of the wrist. A fall on an outstretched hand could result in such a fracture. The fracture can be confirmed (when an x-ray does not show a fracture) if there is pain elicited in the anatomical snuff box on the radial border of the wrist.

An oblique x-ray of the wrist should be able to show a scaphoid fracture.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents with complaints of hip pain for the past few days. She has been taking alendronic acid 10 mg for the treatment of osteoporosis since 6 years. She also takes calcium and vitamin D supplements regularly. What is the next investigation to be done?
questions.solution:
A patient who has been administered bisphosphonates for many years coming with complaints of hip pain arouses suspicion of atypical femur fracture due to long-term bisphosphonate therapy. The next investigation to be done for diagnosis is a plain radiograph.

The first-line medication for reduction of fracture risk in postmenopausal women is oral bisphosphonates therapy with the availability of intravenous formulations as well. Bisphosphonates reduce osteoclastic bone resorption and the general rate of bone turnover. They have been shown to prevent bone loss and to reduce the risk of vertebral and hip fractures.

Prolonged use of bisphosphonates is associated with two potential side effects:

  • Osteonecrosis of the jaw - usually follows a dental procedure.
  • Atypical femur fracture - occurs in the subtrochanteric femoral region or along the shaft distal to the lesser trochanter.

Atypical fractures are those which don't occur at sites typically seen in osteoporosis such as spine, femur (femoral neck and the inter-trochanteric region) or wrist. They instead occur in regions that have increased bone density like the femoral shaft or the subtrochanteric regions. The mechanism of fracture is also atypical wherein it is either atraumatic/low-trauma.

These fractures are thought to occur due to long-term suppression of bone turnover which lowers new bone formation and remodelling. Consequent accumulation of hypermineralized bone which are of poor quality with microcracks are highly susceptible to fractures.

Operative treatment is required for femoral neck and other long bone fractures.

Other options:

Biochemical tests are usually normal in osteoporosis. However, tests like serum calcium, phosphorus, vitamin D, protein, creatinine, alkaline phosphatase, cortisol and parathyroid hormone levels are important in the initial evaluation to rule out differentials and secondary causes of osteoporosis.

The investigation of choice for the diagnosis of osteoporosis is DEXA - dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry. A T-score <–2.5 in the lumbar spine, femoral neck, or total hip has been defined as osteoporosis.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old male patient presents with pain and swelling around the knee joint. His radiographic image is given below. Choose the correct statements regarding his condition.
  1. Radiotherapy is a commonly used treatment modality.
  2. The lesion is usually present in the epiphysis of the bone.
  3. It is associated with periosteal reaction.
  4. A biopsy of the lesion is mandatory before starting treatment.
  5. CT scan of the chest is mandatory during the workup.
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the X-ray image showing sunburst appearance and Codman's triangle in the proximal tibia are suggestive of osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is associated with a periosteal reaction, and a biopsy of the lesion and CT scan of the chest are mandatory steps during the workup of the patient. 

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone, with bimodal age of distribution peaking in adolescence and during the 7th decade. The most common site involved is the metaphysis (statement 2) of distal femur and proximal tibia.

X-rays features include:

  • Codman’s triangle → due to new bone formation in response to periosteal elevation
  • Sunburst appearance → due to new bone formation along the blood vessels within the tumor
  • Periosteal reaction (statement 3) occurs due to the lifting of the periosteum of the bone. Periosteal reaction in osteosarcoma is irregular, unlike in osteomyelitis where it is smooth. 

A biopsy of the tumor should always be carried out before starting treatment (statement 4). The biopsy tract has to be removed during definitive surgery. CT scan of the chest is also mandatory in all cases of osteosarcoma (statement 5) because lung metastases at the time of presentation are common.

Treatment is by wide excision and reconstruction if the tumor is resectable and there are no skip lesions. It is done after starting neoadjuvant chemotherapy for 8-12 weeks. There is no role of radiotherapy in the treatment of osteosarcoma (statement 1). Limb salvage surgeries are preferred over amputation. The principal first-line chemotherapeutic agents used in osteosarcoma are doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate.

questions.text: Bouchard’s nodes are seen in?

choices.text: Both proximal and distal interphalangeal joints

questions.solution:
Bouchard’s nodes are seen in the proximal interphalangeal joint. 

Heberden nodes are the knobby appearance of DIP. They are formed due to the formation of osteophytes and tissue swelling. 

They are the signs of osteoarthritis in hands. 

Osteoarthritis is the most common cause of chronic knee pain in individuals of age >45 years. In the early phases, there is episodic joint pain following overactive use of the diseased joint. As the disease progresses, there is continuous pain and may be associated with stiffness of the affected joint. Morning stiffness if present, is usually brief for around 30 minutes.

The joints involved in osteoarthritis are: 

  • Distal and proximal interphalangeal joints (DIP, PIP)
  • First carpometacarpal joint (base of the thumb)
  • Hip and knee joints
  • First metatarsophalangeal joint (MTP)
  • Cervical and lumbosacral spine

On examination, there is tenderness in the joint. A crepitus is felt on joint movement and the range of movements is painfully restricted. Bouchard's and Heberden's nodes may be palpated in PIP and DIP respectively.

Characteristic features of osteoarthritis seen on plain X-ray are:

  • Marginal osteophyte formation
  • Localized joint space narrowing
  • Sclerosis of the underlying bone
  • Subchondral bone cysts

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with right groin pain. She is a known case of systemic lupus erythematosus for which she has been on steroids for several years. On examination, there is decreased passive and active range of motion of the right hip. You suspect avascular necrosis of the femoral head but the X-ray findings are inconclusive. Which of the following would be the investigation of choice in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient on systemic steroids with groin pain and reduced range of motion in the hip but a normal radiograph is indicative of avascular necrosis of the femoral head. The investigation of choice to diagnose early avascular necrosis is MRI.

MRI allows the identification of avascular necrosis of the femoral head in earlier stages and also helps determine the exact stage and extent of the pathologic process.

Avascular necrosis or osteonecrosis is a degenerative bone condition caused by interruption of the blood supply. It commonly affects the epiphysis of long bones that make up weight-bearing joints. 

The common areas that are affected by avascular necrosis are: 

  • Head of the femur after a fracture of the neck of the femur or hip dislocation
  • Proximal scaphoid after a scaphoid waist fracture
  • Lunate bone after a dislocation
  • Body of the talus after a fracture of the neck of the talus

It is considered to be an early complication of injury, however, it is not clinically evident until weeks to months after the inciting event. There are generally no symptoms associated with avascular necrosis. However, if the fracture does not unite, then there will be a pain. 

An X-ray will reveal increased density. This occurs due to disuse osteoporosis in the surrounding areas and the collapse of trabeculae compacts the bone. There may also be deformity due to the collapse of necrotic bone and osteoarthritis. 

In osteonecrosis of the femur, an X-ray will reveal a crescent sign which is pathognomonic. The sign refers to the subchondral fracture that overlies the necrotic segment of the femoral head. 

The X-ray below shows flattening of the femoral head and degenerative changes associated with osteonecrosis.

The image below shows a crescent sign. 

A bone scan may reveal a 'cold area' before radiological features are evident. MRI is the imaging modality of choice in avascular necrosis as it allows for staging and determination of the extent of involvement. 

It is treated depending on the joint involved. Weight-bearing should be delayed until it is revascularized, a process that may take 6-8 months. Revascularization can be done by using vascularized bone grafts taken from the greater trochanter in the case of a fracture of the femur neck. The avascular segment should be excised followed by a total joint replacement. 

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy complains of pain in the left hip and knee. An X-ray of his left hip was obtained and is given below. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition?
  1. Associated with split in the hypertrophic layer of the growth plate.
  2. Associated with hypothyroidism.
  3. Internal rotation is normal but external rotation is restricted. 
  4. Positive Trethowan's sign.
  5. CT-scan is the investigation of choice.
questions.solution:
The given history and X-ray showing Trethowan's sign point to a diagnosis of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

The Klein line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck which normally intersects the epiphysis. In SCFE, Klein's line does not intersect the epiphysis and passes superior to it. This is known as Trethowan's sign. In SCFE, the slipping of the epiphysis usually occurs through the hypertrophic zone. Multiple endocrine disorders are often associated with SCFE, like hypothyroidism, osteodystrophy of chronic renal failure and excessive growth hormone. 

SCFE occurs during the period of rapid growth, usually during the age of 10-15 years. Risk factors include Obesity, hypothyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all-important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features:

  • Pain in the thigh, groin, or knee.
  • On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated.
  • There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side (statement 3).
  • Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign.
  • Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Investigations:

  • Trethowan's sign is seen in the X-ray.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice (statement 5). 

Treatment consists of in-situ pinning of the epiphysis to the femoral neck

questions.text: A 19-year-old female presents with a deformity in the left lower limb which had developed over time.  The X-ray showed shepherd's crook deformity.  What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:

Fibrous dysplasia is a developmental disorder in which the area of trabecular bone is replaced by cellular fibrous tissue. If this occurs in the weight-bearing bones like the femur, it will lead to the bending of bones called ‘Shepherd’s crook' deformity. 

Patients usually present in childhood or adolescence with pain, limp, deformity, or pathological fracture. Occasionally the bone disorder is associated with cafe-au-lait spots on the skin and in some girls with precocious sexual development (Albright's syndrome).

questions.text: A patient who had a left supracondylar fracture of the humerus a few years back now presents with a progressed deformity as shown in the image given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the deformity?

choices.text: Most commonly involved tendons are flexor digitorum profundus and flexor pollicis longus
The deformity exaggerates on flexing the wrist
Most commonly involved nerve is median nerve
Max Page's operation is done for moderate deformities

questions.solution:
The given deformity is a claw hand seen as a result of Volkmann's ischemic contracture. The deformity exaggerates on extending the wrist(not on flexing).

Ischemic contracture of muscles affected by arterial injury or compartment syndrome is known as Volkmann’s ischaemic contracture (VIC). VIC in the forearm is most commonly seen following supracondylar humeral fractures. The most common nerve involved in VIC is the median nerve. The most common tendons involved are Flexor Digitorum Profundus and Flexor Pollicis Longus.

The classical clinical picture of established Volkmann contracture includes elbow flexion, forearm pronation, wrist flexion, thumb adduction, metacarpophalangeal joint extension, and finger flexion. 

Volkmann's sign: The deformity disappears on flexion and appears on the extension of the wrist.

Treatment of VIC

  • Mild deformities - passive stretching of the contracted muscles with a turn-buckle splint (Volkmann’s splint)
  • Moderate deformities - soft tissue sliding procedures (Max Page operation)
  • Severe deformities - early excision of all necrotic muscles, combined with complete median and ulnar neurolysis. This is followed by a secondary procedure of tendon transfers to restore function. If motor activity is not present in these tendons, a free innervated Gracilis muscle transfer may be considered.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient complains of pain in the right shoulder for the past 3 months. The pain worsens when he tries to comb his hair or touch his back. There is also a restriction of shoulder movements. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with painful restriction of abduction (combing the hair) and internal rotation (touching the back) is suggestive of adhesive capsulitis or frozen shoulder. 

Frozen shoulder is a disorder characterized by progressive pain and stiffness of the shoulder. It usually resolves spontaneously. Frozen shoulder can be primary (idiopathic) or secondary, due to conditions like diabetes mellitus and cardiovascular diseases or as a complication of Colles' fracture. The main clinical feature is a painful restriction of active and passive shoulder movements. External rotation is maximally restricted followed by abduction and internal rotation. 

Frozen shoulder passes through three stages:

  • Stage I (stage of pain) → patient complains of acute pain and movement restriction
  • Stage II (stage of stiffness) → pain gradually decreases and the patient now complains of stiff shoulder
  • Stage III (stage of recovery) → patient will have no pain and movements will gradually recover, but may not return to the normal range of motion

A painful restriction of movement in the presence of normal X-rays and a natural progression through three successive stages are considered to be characteristic of this condition. The diagnosis is made clinically.

Conservative treatment includes analgesics, anti-inflammatory drugs, and pendulum exercises. The condition resolves spontaneously over 18 months but up to 40% of the patients may have some residual symptoms. Surgical treatment is indicated when there is prolonged movement restriction that has failed to respond to conservative management. Arthroscopic capsular release is increasingly being employed to treat frozen shoulder.

Vital signs are within normal limits and physical examination is significant for tenderness over the right fibula proximally.  An X-ray of her right lower limb is shown in the image below. questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a case of an aneurysmal bone cyst. It commonly presents at an age <20 years old and occurs on the metaphysis of long bones.

Aneurysmal bone cyst - 

Aneurysmal bone cysts are benign, locally destructive multiloculated cysts filled with blood. They are eccentric, expansile, and lytic lesions. Most occur in patients younger than 20 years old. There is a slight female preponderance. The most common sites involved are the proximal humerus, distal femur, and proximal tibia. The spine is involved in 15-20% of cases. Presents with pain and swelling. Spinal lesions may cause neurologic deficits or radicular pain.

Clinical features of aneurysmal bone cyst -
Commonly presents in women age <20 years old. Presents as bone pain and swelling for a period of fewer than 6 months.

The below image has an extremely expansive, metaphyseal, lytic lesion, with a short transition zone and non-sclerotic rim, located in the proximal third of the left fibula suggestive of an Aneurysmal bone cyst.

Other Options:

The below X-ray shows expansile, eccentric, sub-articular soap bubble appearance lesion suggestive of Giant cell tumor (Osteoclastoma).

Simple bone cyst- 

  • Simple bone cyst presents most commonly in the first two decades.
  • It is due to the defect in the metaphyseal remodeling which blocks the drainage of interstitial fluid. This leads to increased pressure which leads to focal bone necrosis and accumulation of fluid.
  • Most common site is proximal humeral metaphysis.
  • On radiology, a centrally located, purely lytic lesion with a well-marginated outline is seen.
  • No periosteal reaction is seen unless there is a fracture.

questions.text: Any of the following may be used for the management of a patient with mild scoliosis, except _____.

Braces are used to prevent progression and avoid surgery in scoliotic curves between 20 and 30 degrees. A variety of braces are available, some are created as cast and some are prefabricated. questions.text: A 40-year-old taxi driver presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. The radiograph of his pelvis is shown below. What is the attitude of the limb that you would have seen in the examination, considering the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis of the condition given in the X-ray is posterior dislocation of the left hip joint. On physical examination, the affected limb will be adducted and internally rotated, which is also evident in the X Ray.

The radiograph in left posterior hip dislocation will have the following findings:

  • The femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • The left femoral head appears slightly smaller than the right femoral head
  • The limb is adducted and internally rotated, and hence the lesser trochanter is often obscured/less prominent on AP view.

Posterior dislocation of the hip joint commonly occurs with the dashboard injury. It is more common than an anterior hip dislocation. Shortening of the limb is seen in the posterior type.

As the sciatic nerve lies behind the posterior wall of the acetabulum, it may be damaged with posterior dislocation of the hip.

Methods of closed reduction for posterior hip dislocation are:

  • Allis manoeuvre
  • Stimson manoeuvre
  • East Baltimore lift manoeuvre
  • Bigelow manoeuvre 

In the majority of the cases of posterior hip dislocation, within 6 hours, a closed reduction under general anaesthesia is performed. However, if the reduction is not achieved after two or three attempts, or a CT scan shows the presence of intra-articular bone fragments or larger femoral headpieces that are incompletely reduced, open reduction should be performed.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with complaints of lower backache and stiffness which has been gradually progressive for the past 10 years. The given x-ray shows bamboo spine appearance which is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis. There is a single central radiodense line related to the ossification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments known as dagger sign.

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Insidious onset
  • Morning stiffness 
  • Symptoms begin early at age <40 years
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Persistence for >3 months  

Examination findings:

  • Loss of lumbar lordosis
  • Increased thoracic kyphosis
  • Diminished spinal movements
  • Decreased chest expansion ( <7 cm)

questions.text: The given image shows the x-ray findings of a patient with osteitis deformans. In which phase of the disease are these findings seen?
questions.solution:
The image above shows a blade of grass/ flame-shaped lesion on the x-ray. It is seen in the osteolytic phase of osteitis deformans.

Osteitis deformans is also called Paget's disease of the bone. It is a chronic disease of increased bone turnover in localized areas, resulting in enlarged and thickened bones. There is a significant increase in osteoclastic and osteoblastic activity.

It is usually asymptomatic but can present with dull aching pain unless the disease is severe. Bowing of leg bones may occur. There is an increased risk of pathological fractures and osteosarcoma. 

Paget's disease of the bone is divided into 3 phases:

Osteolytic phase Bone resorption and marked hypervascularization An advancing lytic wedge or blade of grass, or flame-shaped lesion.
Mixed phase Very active bone formation and resorption that replaces normal lamellar bone with haphazard (woven) bone.
  • Picture frame vertebra
  • Ivory vertebra
  • Cotton wool skull
Sclerotic phase

Bone resorption declines progressively and leads to a hard, dense, less vascular pagetic or mosaic bone, which represents the so-called burned-out phase of Paget’s disease.

Serum alkaline phosphate levels may be raised or maybe normal. Treatment is done using intravenous zoledronate given as a single infusion of 4–5 mg.

  • Pectus carinatum: prominent sternum, also known as pigeon chest (option B)

  • Genu varum, genu valgum or wind-swept deformity

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department for pain, erythema, and swelling in the left leg. His symptoms started 4 weeks back, were incompletely managed, and have progressed since then. On physical exam, there is tenderness to palpation of the left leg with a discharging sinus. Laboratory testing is significant for leucocytosis, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein. X-ray findings are shown below. Which of the marked structures acts as a nidus for the chronic infection?

choices.text: There is no nidus as infection is always carried hematogenously

questions.solution:
The patient described in this clinical stem with complaints of pain, swelling, erythema, and a chronic discharging sinus most likely suffers from chronic osteomyelitis. The sequestrum marked as '3' acts as the nidus for infection in such cases. This is because the bacteria within the devascularised sequestrum are protected from antibiotics and the endogenous immune response, thus forming a nidus for chronic infection which may persist for many years even.

Clinical presentation of osteomyelitis - erythema, chronic pain, swelling, tenderness, discharging sinus tract.

When osteomyelitis is suspected on clinical grounds, early radiographs show only the soft tissue swelling, with no bony abnormality. The first bony lesion of osteomyelitis is the periosteal new bone formation. It is seen on an X-ray radiograph by the 2nd week of infection. It appears as a faint extracortical outline. Hence, the following imaging modalities are used to aid early diagnosis:

  • MRI: Marrow edema is seen within 24-48hr. A normal MRI can rule out osteomyelitis.
  • Technetium 99 bone scan: Osteomyelitis will show increased osseous uptake of the tracer whereas other soft tissue infections will not show osseous uptake. A normal bone scan rules out osteomyelitis.

X-ray findings are as shown below - 

 

1 - Involucrum is the thick sheath of periosteal new bone that surrounds the sequestrum.

2- Cloacae is an opening in an involucrum that allows the drainage of purulent and necrotic material out of the dead bone.

3 - Sequestrum is a piece of devitalized bone that has been separated from its surrounding bone during the process of necrosis. Acts as a nidus for chronic infection.

 

Lab investigations show a raised ESR and CRP and leucocytosis as seen in this patient.

questions.text: An infant with a large head and normal length was brought with failure to thrive. On examination hepatosplenomegaly and frontal bossing were noted. Blood tests show pancytopenia and X-ray imaging is done which is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A presentation of failure to thrive in an infant with a large head, normal length, pancytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, and the X-ray image showing dense bones is suggestive of osteopetrosis. 

Osteopetrosis/Marble bone disease/Albers–Schönberg disease:

It is a disorder involving defective bone resorption due to mutation of CLCN7 (in osteoclasts).

Clinical features: Macrocephaly (due to hydrocephalus), developmental delay, pancytopenia (reduced bone marrow cavity), and hepatosplenomegaly (compensatory extramedullary hematopoiesis)

Blood investigation: Low serum calcium and phosphorus levels with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) and normal vitamin D levels.

Radiological features: Plain radiographs are usually diagnostic. Diffuse bone sclerosis with clubbing of metaphyses. Bone within the bone appearance and "sandwich" appearance of the vertebral bodies can be seen. The skull base shows uniform radiodensity

Treatment: Symptomatic treatment and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation can be done.

questions.text: A teenager sustained an injury to his middle finger while attempting to catch a basketball during a match. On examination, his finger appeared as shown below. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

questions.text:
Arrange the following deformities in the order that they occur during the clinical course of tuberculosis of the hip.
  1. Flexion, adduction, apparent shortening
  2. Fibrous ankylosis
  3. Flexion, abduction, apparent lengthening
  4. Flexion, adduction, true shortening
  5. Pestle and mortar deformity
questions.solution:
The clinical course of tuberculosis of the hip has been divided into the following stages:

  1. Stage of synovitis presents with flexion, abduction, external rotation, and apparent lengthening of the limb due to joint effusion.
  2. Stage of early arthritis presents with flexion, adduction, internal rotation, and apparent shortening of the limb.
  3. Stage of advanced arthritis presents with the same deformities as early arthritis, except there is a true shortening of the limb because of the destruction of the articular cartilage of the femur and the acetabulum.
  4. Stage of advanced arthritis with subluxation leads to destruction of acetabulum and dislocation of the femur head. This is also known as wandering acetabulum/ mortar and pestle hip.
  5. Tuberculosis of the hip finally results in fibrous ankylosis of the hip joint.

questions.text: All of the following are indications of surgery in a patient of Potts' spine except?

choices.text: Progressive cauda equina syndrome/conus medullaris syndrome

questions.solution:
A cold abscess without neurological complications is not an indication for surgery in Pott’s spine/TB spine.

Indications of surgery in TB spine are:

  • Progressive neurologic deficit such as progressive cauda equina syndrome/conus medullaris syndrome (Option D)
  • Progressive increase in spinal deformity
  • Resistance to anti-tubercular therapy (Option C)
  • Recurrence of disease
  • Cord compression
  • Severe pain due to abscess or spinal instability
  • Progressive impairment of pulmonary function
  • Uncertain diagnosis (Option B): Inability to obtain a microbiological diagnosis through microscopy, culture, or PCR techniques may occur. In cases where there is no accessible source for sampling (such as discharging sinus or superficial abscess) or insufficient specimen obtained from image-guided percutaneous biopsy, an open surgical biopsy is the only option to obtain a specific culture and sensitivity report.

Antero-lateral decompression is the surgery of choice for Pott’s paraplegia as it helps in the removal of both solid and liquid debris.

Inter-trochanteric fracture of the femur is sustained in the elderly due to a sideways fall or an injury to the greater trochanter. It can also occur in young patients following a road traffic accident. The patient is brought with pain and swelling in the groin region. On examination, the leg is shortened > 1cm and externally rotated > 45°. The physical findings are usually more marked than in fracture of the neck of the femur.

questions.text: A 26-year old athlete presented with sudden pain in her right knee after performing a heavy deadlift. On examination of the joint, swelling is present and McMurray's test is positive. X-ray appears normal. Which of the following structures is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and a positive McMurray's test indicate a meniscal injury.

In this test, the patient is made to lie in the supine position and the knee is completely flexed. One hand is used to stabilize and palpate the knee joint, while the other hand is used to internally or externally rotate the leg, depending on which meniscus is to be tested. The leg is then slowly extended. Any palpable or audible click indicates injury to the menisci.

Other tests used to detect meniscal injury include:

  • Apley's grinding test
  • Thessaly test
  • Squat test
  • Ege's test
  • Joint line tenderness test

Apley's test: In this test, the patient is made to lie in the prone position. The knee is flexed to 90º and rotated while a compression force is applied, which is called the grinding test. The reproduction of symptoms indicates a torn meniscus. The distraction test involves repeated rotation while the leg is pulled upwards by the examiner, holding the thigh down. This produces increased pain only if there is ligament damage.

Thessaly test: With the affected knee flexed to 20º and the foot placed flat on the ground, the patient bears his full weight on that leg while being supported by the examiner. The patient is then asked to twist his or her body to one side and then to the other three times. This test has shown a high diagnostic accuracy rate (95%) in detecting meniscal tears.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy sustained an injury to the elbow which was managed by plaster application. Two years later he presents with paresthesias over the little finger & the medial half of the ring finger. Clinical examination reveals a deformity as shown below. questions.solution:
The deformity shown in the image is a partial claw hand indicating an ulnar nerve injury. The given history of an injury around the elbow which was managed conservatively and has led to ulnar nerve dysfunction over 2 years points to a diagnosis of tardy ulnar nerve palsy, which is a late complication of fracture of the lateral condyle of the humerus. 

Decreased growth on the lateral aspect of the distal humerus epiphysis leads to cubitus valgus deformity. This can cause late (tardy) ulnar nerve palsy because of friction neuritis of the ulnar nerve as it moves over the medial epicondyle during flexion and extension of the elbow. 

A developing tardy ulnar nerve palsy requires transposing the ulnar nerve anterior to the medial epicondyle to prevent further friction damage. Mild cubitus valgus deformity without any nerve palsy is managed conservatively. A moderate to severe valgus deformity may require supracondylar osteotomy.

In ulnar nerve injury, there is

  • Hyperextension at metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at interphalangeal joints. This causes claw hand deformity.
  • There is also sensory loss in the medial one-third of the palm and the medial one-and-a-half fingers.
  • The patient is unable to abduct the fingers due to paralysis of the dorsal interossei muscles. Egawa test is done to test the function of dorsal interossei muscles.
  • The patient is also unable to adduct the fingers due to paralysis of the palmar interossei muscles. Card test is done to test the function of palmar interossei muscles.
  • Positive book test or Froment's sign occurs due to weakness of the adductor pollicis muscle. When asked to hold a book, the patient tries to hold the book by using flexor pollicis longus muscle. This produces flexion at the interphalangeal joint while holding the book.

questions.solution:
The clinical features and x-ray given in the question are suggestive of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. The most common nerve injured in this fracture is the anterior interosseus branch of the median nerve, which supplies the flexor pollicis longus muscle. Weakness of this muscle can lead to weakness in the flexion of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb. 

Supracondylar fracture of the humerus is most commonly seen in children of 5-7 years after a fall on an outstretched hand with the elbow in full extension. It is most commonly of extension type followed by flexion type. Gartland classification is used for supracondylar fractures. The three-point bony relationship is maintained in supracondylar fracture (option B). Three-point bony landmarks in the elbow are the tips of medial and lateral epicondyles and the olecranon.

Nerve and vessel injury:

  • Most common nerve to be injured in extension type - anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve > Ulnar nerve. (AMRU)
  • Most common nerve to be injured in flexion type - Ulnar nerve.
  • Most common vessel to be injured - brachial artery.

Radiological findings:  

  • An undisplaced fracture may show a triangular lucency like a sail of a yacht (sail sign), also called a fat pad sign. This is due to the fat pad around the elbow being pushed forward by the hematoma.
  • Baumann’s angle (humeral-capitellar angle) can help in assessing the degree of medial angulation before and after reduction (option C).

The most common complication of supracondylar fracture is malunion. This leads to cubitus varus or gunstock deformity. Malunion occurs due to improper reduction and not due to physeal damage, as the fracture is extraphyseal (option D). Other complications include myositis ossificans, compartment syndrome, and Volkmann ischemic contracture. 

Undisplaced supracondylar humerus fractures are treated by an above-elbow plaster slab with the elbow in 90º flexion. Displaced fractures are treated by closed reduction and K-wire fixation since they tend to slip after reduction. Open fractures or those associated with brachial artery injury are treated by open reduction and internal fixation.

Cubitus varus deformity is corrected after skeletal maturation and lateral closed-wedge osteotomy (French osteotomy) is the method employed.
